channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Your Epic Sports Weekend Primer
item.description: Golf Keyur Khamar/PGA TOUR via Getty Images The PGA Championship is entering the third round at the stunning-but-gusty Ocean Course at Kiawah Island in South Carolina.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 22
item.description: (Morning Brew) Read: In the final installment of our series on Black Wall Street, we collected a list of resources to help you learn more about the Tulsa Race Massacre of 1921.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Tribune’s Shareholders Approve Sale to Alden
item.description: Despite loads of opposition, shareholders voted yesterday to approve the sale of Tribune Publishing and its legendary newspaper chain—including the Chicago Tribune, Baltimore Sun, and a number of other local dailies—to Alden Global Capital for $633 million.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Vaccine Tracker: May 22
item.description: Use vaccines as an aphrodisiac: In partnership with the White House, popular dating apps including Hinge, Tinder, OkCupid, and Bumble will soon introduce features that allow users to a) broadcast they’ve been vaccinated and b) find other vaccinated singles who are down to dose-si-do.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Trial Between Epic Games and Apple Is Over
item.description: But even if it ends up defeating Epic, this trial has perma-flipped flashlight mode onto Apple’s App Store. Cook also argued that Apple does not closely track the App Store’s profit and loss; in other words, the company’s bean-counting doesn’t interfere with the App Store’s integrity as a marketplace for users to discover apps.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: The Trial Between Epic Games and Apple Is Over
item.description: But even if it ends up defeating Epic, this trial has perma-flipped flashlight mode onto Apple’s App Store. Cook also argued that Apple does not closely track the App Store’s profit and loss; in other words, the company’s bean-counting doesn’t interfere with the App Store’s integrity as a marketplace for users to discover apps.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Tulsa Race Massacre: Learn More About What Happened
item.description: Nia Clark’s Dreams of Black Wall Street series offers a deep dive into the riots, but also reflects on the massacre’s legacy, including Greenwood’s continued economic struggles, racial tensions, and the unsolved mystery of where the bodies are buried. It runs through everything from national and local factors that precipitated the event to the massacre itself to the aftermath. Go deeper on what happened May 31 and June 1Read: In 1921, journalist Walter White, who would later become the NAACP director, was sent to Tulsa to write about what happened for The Nation.  ABC’s Soul of a Nation shares the stories of survivors and looks at how the city is still working to heal those wounds.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Tribune’s Shareholders Approve Sale to Alden
item.description: When the deal is finalized, Alden will take Tribune private and become the second-largest newspaper owner in the country.

item.title: Make It Work: Recruiting Takeover
item.description: When you apply and are asked about your current company/role, my suggestion would be to reference notable companies, brands, or clients you work with along with the less-recognizable name of the smaller company you work for. is a question I get asked in every interview.  You can always check the Glassdoor profile of a company you’re applying to, but take it with a grain of salt since reviews on there can sometimes be really old. Everyone says working for a small company/startup leads to valuable skills, but many recruiters may not recognize the company's name.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Meme Battle: Classy Winnie the Pooh
item.description: We'll pick a new memelord in next week's Sunday Edition and provide you with another meme template to meme-ify.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: How to Not Get (Totally) Ripped Off When Ordering Wine
item.description: They analyzed the prices of 6,335 wines at 249 London restaurants to understand how wine markups at restaurants really work. And for the rest of us who order the average-priced wine of the list... Much has been said about the pitfalls of ordering the second-cheapest bottle of wine on a menu.  What they found: People who order the second-cheapest bottle of wine are in fact not being ripped off more than anyone else. The wines in the middle of the menu, the Pittsburgh Pirates of the wine world, have the highest percentage markup. You pick up the wine men—er, scan the QR code to pull up the wine list.   So how are wine menus priced?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...Aparicio Giddins
item.description: The book that I read in college that made me want to start a bank was Rich Dad, Poor Dad.What's a song that can always pump you up? Aparicio Giddins is the president and chief technology officer of Greenwood Financial, a new banking platform for Black and Latino customers. What new ways of doing things will you keep from this past year? I want to make sure that I continue getting outdoors because it really is beautiful out there. This interview was lightly edited and condensed for clarity. It's a shame I've been stuck in a concrete building for the last 20 years.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Brew Crossword: Cover Your Bases
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Billionaire Barry Diller's $260 Million Island Opens this Weekend
item.description: If you can't find us this weekend, check the 2.4-acre floating Little Island, which opens today on New York City's west side.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Robinhood Now Offering IPO Shares
item.description: The guinea pig: Figs, a maker of medical scrubs, became the first company to offer IPO shares on Robinhood when it went public yesterday, reserving 1% of its 22.5 million shares for Robinhood users. Companies popped an average of 36% on their first day of trading in 2020, per Dealogic.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Oatly IPOs at $12B valuation
item.description: But the company didn't become a household name until Petersson took over as CEO in 2014, refreshing Oatly's visual identity and reframing its marketing around oat milk's health and environmental benefits. Yesterday, shares in Oatly, the world's biggest oat milk maker, soared 19% in its IPO, valuing the company at a trenta-sized $12 billion. In the oat department alone, Oatly's got competition from Califia Farms, Chobani, Planet Oat, Pacific, and Danone's legacy alternative milk brands, Alpro and Silk. oat milk? But oat milk is still second fiddle to almond milk. Their bet is paying off.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: In finance, 'people of color are shut out before they ever get in'
item.description: There just aren't that many people of color in finance, even in New York City. Now we in finance are starting to pay attention to diversity. There are more of us now—maybe because banks realized sitting in a room with only 15 white men was a bad look. People of color are shut out before they ever get in. Do I talk to the seven people of color who work in finance? It's just you, the only woman on the floor and one of the few people of color on the floor. When Wells Fargo's CEO says he can't find qualified people of color when I personally have them reaching out to me on LinkedIn every day? I had friends of color from college who happened to be in the finance industry In speaking to my friends of color in different parts of the finance industry, our experiences were analogous. I think the finance industry wants to change. Maybe there aren't seven Black people anymore, but eight. You feel like you work harder than your coworkers with no recognition." I had a friend of color in my cohort and we were among the only people who got the job based on our interviews and credentials, and not who our family was, or who knew someone. We're hardly giving those same chances to people of color. Just to get me in the stadium, essentially. It's so hard to get your foot in the door. You're not seeing the fruits of your labor. In 2015 I received a new manager who happened to be a white man. Sure, there were one or two other Black men, but trying to fit into the culture—the culture of white people, to be frank—was difficult. There was one woman at my bank, more senior, who I could talk to as a kind of mentor. You can see the change particularly when there are industry happy hours and events. But it can be a hard few months or years. I don't know. I'm sure my story is not unique for people of color in finance.
item.author: Sandrine Maurice

item.title: The Brew’s Weekly News Quiz: May 21

item.title: Billionaire Barry Diller's $260 Million Island Opens this Weekend
item.description: If you can't find us this weekend, check the 2.4-acre floating Little Island, which opens today on New York City's west side. + Doesn't it also kinda look like the Cracker Barrel peg game? The relocation of the Whitney Museum in 2015, the High Line park, and Google's expansion in Chelsea have dramatically changed the area in the last decade.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Robinhood Now Offering IPO Shares
item.description: The guinea pig: Figs, a maker of medical scrubs, became the first company to offer IPO shares on Robinhood when it went public yesterday, reserving 1% of its 22.5 million shares for Robinhood users. Companies popped an average of 36% on their first day of trading in 2020, per Dealogic.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Oatly IPOs at $12B valuation
item.description: Yesterday, shares in Oatly, the world's biggest oat milk maker, soared 19% in its IPO, valuing the company at a trenta-sized $12 billion. In the oat department alone, Oatly's got competition from Califia Farms, Chobani, Planet Oat, Pacific, and Danone's legacy alternative milk brands, Alpro and Silk. oat milk? But the company didn't become a household name until Petersson took over as CEO in 2014, refreshing Oatly's visual identity and reframing the company’s marketing around oat milk's health and environmental benefits.   But oat milk is still second fiddle to almond milk. Their bet is paying off.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Air Travel Already Surging Before EU’s Reopening Announcement
item.description: Back stateside: While some American travelers are waiting for the final EU approval that will likely come later this month or next before booking international flights, US domestic travel has already taken off. United added 400 new domestic and international flights to July’s schedule to prepare for the expected surge in summer travels.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: F-150 Lightning: A Lot Riding on Ford’s First All-Electric Truck
item.description: In an extravagant event last night, Ford officially unveiled its all-electric F-150 Lightning. Since many Americans may view EVs as the domain of the Berkeley crowd, Ford hopes that an electric version of the ubiquitous F-150 could change perceptions.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Cryptocurrencies Including Bitcoin, Ethereum Plunge In Value
item.description: PwC’s global head of crypto Henri Arslanian: “I would not be surprised to see other regulators and policymakers do the same [as the Chinese restrictions] over the coming weeks as they warn investors over the risks of speculative trading or crypto market volatility.”  Some other reasons investors could be hopping off the crypto coaster: New investors in the space may have learned Monday that the IRS treats cryptocurrency as property, not currency, and taxes it as such. But yesterday, amid the market chaos, Musk confirmed his overall support for bitcoin with a tweet: “Tesla has 💎 🙌” On a crazy day for crypto, everyone had something to sayLet’s pass the mic...
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Internet Explorer Gets Edged Out
item.description: In 2013, Google Chrome overtook Internet Explorer as the most popular browser in the US and hasn’t looked back. According to NetMarketShare, Chrome owns 69% of the market, Edge 7.8%, Firefox 7.5%, and Internet Explorer 5.2%.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 20
item.description: (ProPublica) Read: Hundreds of PPP loans went to fake farms in absurd places.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Why Banking With Greenwood Is About More Than the Money
item.description: In March, Greenwood raised a $40 million Series A from Truist Bank, Bank of America, and JPMorgan Chase, and most recently, Greenwood partnered with Mastercard to create its first debit card and other educational resources for customers. Greenwood Financial’s founders were inspired by the prosperity of the Greenwood District. Greenwood’s fully digital platform allows people to bank with them from all over the country, specifically in areas that have been shunned by traditional banks, known as bank deserts. But it’s not just about making Greenwood’s services accessible; its users have to trust it, which means reframing the fraught relationship between the US financial institutions and Black Americans. And Greenwood, we're making the Black version of that movie.” As of last June, only 0.2% of all banks regulated by the FDIC were Black-owned, and the number of Black-owned banks has been cut in half since 2001. In the early 1900s, the Greenwood District of Tusla, Oklahoma—often referred to as Black Wall Street—was home to a thriving Black business community.  “You can get Apple Pay and Google Pay, you can get a savings account, a spending account, and you can go to the ATM. The digital banking platform is designed specifically for Black and Latino customers who have historically been denied access to credit and other financial services at much higher rates than white customers. Giddins mentions Italian-American Amadeo Giannini who founded Bank of America, at the time called “Bank of Italy,” in 1904 as a way to provide loans to immigrants who were denied by major financial institutions.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Amazon Reportedly Negotiating $9B Acquisition of MGM Studios
item.description: AT&T's WarnerMedia just confirmed that it’s merging with Discovery into a $120+ billion entertainment giant next year.  Zoom out: News of a potential MGM acquisition comes against the backdrop of an increasingly competitive streaming landscape.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Google Announces Slate of New Features
item.description: On Google Search, you'll be able to... In Google Photos... Big picture: Parent Alphabet may have scaled back some moonshot projects, but it continues to use Google's cash-cow advertising unit to invest in futuristic services that range from practical to pie-in-the-sky.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Teens Can Now Trade Stocks With Fidelity
item.description: when teens with Fidelity Youth Accounts turn 18, their account switches into Fidelity's standard brokerage offering for grown-ups.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: IEA Sets out 400+ Step Plan to Reach 2050 Climate Goals
item.description: So the IEA went full Leslie Knope and released 400+ milestones for governments, including... And, based on existing national targets, the IEA estimates that by 2050 there will still be 22 billion tons of CO2 emissions. In a halftime speech for the ages, the International Energy Agency released a major report yesterday urging countries to go out there and score their 2050 climate goals. The gameplanSome countries have taken big steps—Denmark pledged an end to new fossil fuel exploration, the UK is phasing out new sales of gas-powered vehicles.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Google Announces Slate of New Features
item.description: On Google Search, you'll be able to...  But wait, there's more: Google plans to drop a few billi on building the first-ever commercial-grade quantum computer by 2029.
item.author: Jamie Wilde
